node.text: A conversation with landscape architect Janice Parker

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine on August 03, 2021. May be an image of tree, outdoors and text that says 'CALL FOR ENTRIES! VERANDA Best of OUTDOOR LIVING 2022 Our 3RD ANNUAL AWARDS Recognizing Excellence in Landscape Design (NOW, WITH NEW CATEGORIES!)'.

node.text:
It’s awards season! And this one’s sure to be a blockbuster on the heels of a year spent reimagining, replanting, reawakening our gardens and terraces. For Veranda’s Best of Outdoor Living 2022, send us your gardens (country, urban & suburban spaces), greenhouses, pools, porches, loggias, courtyards, dining terraces, & more! PLUS, NEW THIS YEAR: Nominate landscape visionaries in the categories of botanical innovation, original approach to design, wellness, preservation, and lifetime achievement.

Judges Bunny Williams and Institute of Classical Architecture & Art president Peter Lyden, along with Veranda editors, will choose the winners, announced in our March/April 2022 issue. 

Tap the link in bio to learn how to enter, and tag someone who should enter in the comments!
-
Garden design by Scott Shrader (@scott_shrader)
Photography by Lisa Romerein (@lisaromerein)

node.text:
For you, dozens of peonies to brighten up the day. 💐

#regram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Veranda Magazine on August 03, 2021 tagging @pegasus_books. May be an image of ‎book and ‎text that says '‎VERANDA BOOK CLUB AUGUST 2021 JشE Olivia Williams The SECRET 中 LIFE ofthe SAVOY Glmu Glamour nd Intr World's Most Famous Hotel‎'‎‎.

node.text:
It's that time again! 📚Our August pick for the VERANDA Sip and Read Club is Olivia Williams's 'The Secret Life of the Savoy,' a fascinating look at the most luxurious hotels in the world, the Savoy Hotel in London. 

This month, we will be hosting an Instagram live with Olivia. To learn more about the selection, tap the link in bio! Happy reading! 

#versipandreadclub

Did someone say it was tea time? ✨

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Jupiter Island, Florida. May be an image of table and living room.

node.text:
The cozy breakfast room of this Betsy Brown-designed home on Jupiter Island has become a family-favorite space to catch up on conversation or a crossword, and, of course, sip coffee into the afternoon.  Brown (@betsybrowninc) shopped coast-to-coast to find just the right items that were still beautiful but could hold up to a house full of kids and dogs for years to come. The pendant (@fordhuniford) casts a glow over vintage dining chairs by French designer Charlotte Perriand.

Tap the link to see inside this Jupiter Island retreat.
—
Photography by Nicole Franzen (@nicole_franzen).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in East Hampton, New York. May be an image of living room.

node.text:
Found: the coziest reading spot courtesy of designer Charlotte Moss (@charmossny). Imari lamps (@vaughandesigns) provide lighting for two areas where Moss often works: the Louis XV bureau plat on which they stand and the sofa (RH)  in front. 
—
Photography by Melanie Acevedo (@melanieacevedophoto), from the VER archives.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Nantucket. May be an image of flower and outdoors.

node.text:
Hydrangea season is in full bloom. ✨ 
—
📸: @vic_nkt
#regram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Maine. May be an image of furniture, tree, outdoors and living room.

node.text:
Not a bad place to kick the weekend off at. Architect Gil Schafer (@gpschafer) used painted shingles—a classic look in Maine—on this idyllic cottage to give the edges a less punctuated look and elongate its appearance. Custom sliding windows keep the waterfront porch comfortable when the winds pick up off the harbor.

See more of this cozy Maine cottage at the link in bio.
—
Landscape design by Stephen Mohr
Photography by Eric Piasecki (@ericpiasecki)
Styling by Helen Crowther (@helencrowther)
As told to Stephanie Hunt (@stephhuntwrites)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Washington, Connecticut. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
“It couldn’t be too perfect,” says Gorrivan of the renovation of this 1750s home in Washington, Connecticut. “That’s just not the way people live today.”

The New York-based designer sought to preserve the 270-year-old home's historic charm while ensuring it lasted for another hundred years. Building codes required that the narrow front hall staircase be replaced. But because “it’s a beautiful architectural element,” Gorrivan says, they kept it in place and satisfied modern codes by adding new stairs toward the back of the house.

Tap the link in bio to see more of this 1750s Connecticut home.
—

Photography by Joshua McHugh (@joshuamchughphotography)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Upper West Side. May be an image of furniture and indoor.

node.text:
Let's get into the details. Throughout this Upper West Side apartment, Anthony Baratta (@tonybaratta) relied on trims and woven tapes to emphasize the contours of furnishings and bring the composition of each room into focus. The New York-based decorator compares this technique to the “the outlines in a coloring book.”

The seat back panel is lifted from the sofa’s indigo urn fabric and echoes the shape of the client’s plates and platters mounted in the kitchen beyond. Plaster sconces (@paulferrante.inc) and crystal candelabras frame the fireplace and add to the room’s sense of fantasy. 

Take a full tour of this Manhattan apartment at the link in bio!
–
Photography by Mark Roskams (@mark_roskams)
Written by Celia Barbour

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Kips Bay Decorator Show House. May be an image of living room.

node.text:
Is your favorite designer participating in this year's Kips Bay Decorator Show House in Dallas (@kbshowhouse)? You can check by tapping the link in our bio. 

Before you go though, let's take a minute to look back at this tranquil living by Viviano Viviano (@_viviano_viviano_) from last year's show. This intimate living space was inspired by the design firm’s go-to reference points for comfort: the informal dens of English and Italian country houses. Velvet chaises covered in Perennials fabric (@perennialsfabrics) and The Shade Store’s (@theshadestore) wool flannel Roman shades make the room feel insulated and indulgently cozy.
—
Photography by Stephen Karlisch (@stephen_karlisch_photo)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine on July 26, 2021. May be an image of flower.

node.text:
And just like that, poppies became our new favorite flower. ✨
—
Floral design by Kiana Underwood of Tulipina (@tulipinadesign)
#regram
